article.paragraph: Alexander Selkirk(1676spaced ndash13 December 1721), also known asAlexander Selcraig, was a Scottish sailor who spent more than four years as acastawayafter beingmarooningmaroonedon an uninhabited island in theSouth Pacific Ocean(also known as the South Sea).

Selkirk was an unruly youth, and joinedbuccaneeringexpeditions to theSouth Pacific OceanSouth Sea. One such expedition was aboard theCinque Ports (1703 ship)Cinque Ports, commanded byWilliam Dampier. The ship called in for provisions at theJuan Fernndez Islandsoff Chile, and Selkirk judged correctly that his craft was unseaworthy and asked to be left there.

By the time that he was rescued, he had become adept at hunting and making use of the resources that he found on the island. His story of survival was widely publicised when he returned home and became a likely source of inspiration for writerDaniel Defoe's fictional characterRobinson Crusoe.cite bookTimSeverin2002In Search of Robinson CrusoeBasic BooksNew York17–19978-046-50-7698-7
article.heading: Early life and privateering
article.paragraph: Alexander Selkirk was the son of a shoemaker and tanner inLower Largo,Fife, Scotland, born in 1676.sfnpHowell182918–19In his youth, he displayed a quarrelsome and unruly disposition. He was summoned before theKirk Sessionin August 1693sfnpTakahashiCaldwellCáceresCalderón2007n. 11, "Date of 1693, verified from the original Kirk Session Records (CH2/960/2, pp. 29, 30), is erroneously given in other printed sources as 1695."for his "indecent conduct in church", but he "did not appear, being gone to sea." He was back at Largo in 1701, when he again came to the attention of church authorities for beating up his brothers.sfnpHowell182924–25

Early on, he was engaged in buccaneering. In 1703, he joined an expedition of Englishprivateerand explorerWilliam Dampierto theSouth Pacific OceanSouth Sea,sfnpFunnell17071–2setting sail fromKinsalein Ireland on 11 September.sfnpFunnell17073They carriedletters of marquefrom thePrince George of DenmarkLord High Admiralauthorising their armed merchant ships to attack foreign enemies, as theWar of the Spanish Successionwas then going on between England and France.cite webhttp://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/pathways/blackhistory/journeys/voyage_html/transcripts/stgeorge.htmLetters of Marque and Reprisal for the St George, Declaration of William DampierThe National ArchivesOctober 13, 1702Dampier wascaptain (nautical)captainof theSt George,and Selkirk served on theCinque Ports (1703 ship)Cinque Ports,St George's companion ship, assailing masterunder CaptainThomas Stradling.sfnpHowell182933, 37–38By this time, Selkirk must have had considerable experience at sea.sfnpHowell182924–25

In February 1704, following a stormy passage roundCape Horn,sfnpFunnell170714–15the privateers fought a long battle with a well-armed French vessel, theSt Joseph, only to have it escape to warn the Spanish of the buccaneers' arrival in the Pacific.sfnpFunnell170726A raid failed on the Panamanian gold mining town of Santa Mara when their landing party wasambushed.sfnpFunnell170744–45The easy capture of theAsuncin, a heavily-laden merchantman, revived the men's hopes of plunder, and Selkirk was put in charge of theprize ship. Dampier took off some much-needed provisions of wine, brandy, sugar, and flour, then abruptly set the ship free, believing that the gain was not worth the effort. In May 1704, Stradling decided to abandon Dampier and strike out on his own.sfnpFunnell170745–47
article.heading: Castaway
article.paragraph: File:Rob-cru.pngthumbleftalt=Shaded relief map of the Juan Fernndez Islands with blue ocean he died on the island backgroundMap of theJuan Fernndez Islands, where Selkirk lived as a castawayIn September 1704, after parting ways with Dampier,sfnpFunnell170746–47Captain Stradling brought theCinque Portsto an island known to the Spanish asMs a Tierra, located in the uninhabitedJuan Fernndez IslandsJuan Fernndez archipelago,convert670kmmi-1onoff the coast of Chile, for a mid-expedition restocking of fresh water and supplies.sfnpLee1987394–395

Selkirk had grave concerns about the seaworthiness of their vessel and probably wanted to make the needed repairs before going any farther. He declared that he would rather be left on Juan Fernndez than continue in a dangerously leaky ship. Stradling granted his request and landed Selkirk and his personal effects on the island. Selkirk regretted his rashness, but Stradling refused to let him back on board.sfnpRogers1712125

Cinque Portsdid indeed later founder off the coast of what is nowColombia. Stradling and some of his crew survived the loss of their ship but were forced to surrender to the Spanish. The survivors were taken toLima, Peru, where they endured a harsh imprisonment.sfnpRogers1712145, 333
article.heading: Life on the island
article.paragraph: At first, Selkirk remained along the shoreline of Juan Fernndez. During this time, he atejasus(spiny lobsters) and scanned the ocean daily for rescue, suffering all the while from loneliness, misery, and remorse. Hordes of raucousMirounga leoninasea lionsgathered on the beach for the mating season, and they eventually drove him to the island's interior.sfnpSteele1713169–171Once inland, his way of life took a turn for the better. More foods were available there:feral goatsintroduced by earlier sailorsprovided him with meat and milk, while wildturnips,Dendroseris litoraliscabbage leaves, and driedpink peppercornpepper berriesoffered him variety and spice.Ratswould attack him at night, but he was able to sleep soundly and in safety by domesticating and living nearferal cats.sfnpRogers1712127–128

File:Selkirk reading his Bible.pngthumbrightalt=Engraving of Selkirk sitting in the doorway of a hut reading a BibleSelkirk reading his Bible in one of two huts that he built on a mountainsideSelkirk proved resourceful in using materials that he found on the island: he forged a new knife out ofbarrelhoops left on the beach, he built two huts out ofSchinus mollepeppertrees (one of which he used for cooking and the other for sleeping), and he employed his musket to hunt goats and his knife to clean their carcasses. As his gunpowder dwindled, he had to chase prey on foot. During one such chase, he was badly injured when he tumbled from a cliff, lying helpless and unable to move for about a day. His prey had cushioned his fall, likely sparing him a broken back.sfnpRogers1712126–128

His childhood lessons now served him well which he had learned from his father, a tanner. For example, when his clothes wore out, he made new ones from hair-covered goatskins using a nail for sewing.sfnpRogers1712128As his shoes became unusable, he had no need to replace them, since his toughened, callused feet made protection unnecessary.sfnpRogers1712128He sangPsalms#The Psalms in Christian worshippsalmsand read from theKing James BibleBible, finding it a comfort in his situation and a prop for his English.sfnpRogers1712126

During his sojourn on the island, two vessels came to anchor. Unfortunately for Selkirk, both were Spanish. As a Scotsman and a privateer, he risked a grim fate if captured and, therefore, tried to hide himself. On one occasion, he was spotted and chased by a group of sailors from one of the ships. His pursuers urinated beneath the tree in which he was hiding, but failed to discover him. Frustrated, his would-be captors gave up and sailed away.sfnpRogers1712125
article.heading: Rescue
article.paragraph: File:Serkirk being taken aboard the Duke.jpgthumbalt=Selkirk, seated in a ship's boat, being taken aboard the ''Duke''.The rescued Selkirk, seated at right, being taken aboard the ''Duke''.Selkirk's long-awaited deliverance came on 2 February 1709 by way of theDuke,sfnpRogers1712124–125a privateering shipmaritime pilotpilotedbyWilliam Dampier, and its sailing companion theDuchess.sfnpRogers17126Thomas Doverled the landing party that met Selkirk.sfnpRogers1712124After four years and four months without human company, Selkirk was almost incoherent with joy.sfnpRogers1712129TheDuke'scaptain and leader of the expedition wasWoodes Rogers, who mischievously referred to him as the governor of the island. The agile castaway caught two or three goats a day, and helped restore the health of Rogers' men, who were suffering fromscurvy.sfnpRogers1712131–132

Captain Rogers was impressed by Selkirk's physical vigour, and also by the peace of mind that he had attained while living on the island, observing: "One may see that solitude and retirement from the world is not such an insufferable state of life as most men imagine, especially when people are fairly called or thrown into it unavoidably, as this man was."sfnpRogers1712130He made Selkirk theDuke'ssecond mate, later giving him command of one of their prize ships, theIncrease,sfnpRogers1712147before it was ransomed by the Spanish.sfnpRogers1712220

Selkirk returned to privateering with a vengeance. AtGuayaquil, in present-day Ecuador, he led a boat crew up theGuayas River, where a number of wealthy Spanish ladies had fled, and relieved them of the gold and jewels they had hidden inside their clothing.sfnpRogers1712178–179His part in the hunt for treasureManila galleongalleonsalong the coast of Mexico resulted in the capture of theNuestra Seora de la Encarnacin y Desengao,sfnpRogers1712294renamedBatchelor, on which he served as sailing master under Captain Dover to theDutch East Indies.sfnpRogers1712312Selkirk completed the round-the-world voyage by theDutch Cape ColonyCape of Good Hopeas the sailing master of theDuke,sfnpCooke171261arriving atthe Downsoff the English coast on 1 October 1711.sfnpRogers1712427He had been away for eight years.sfnpFunnell17073
article.heading: Later life and influence
article.paragraph: File:Robinson svensk1732.jpgthumbleftupright=0.65alt=Engraving of Robinson Crusoe standing on the shore of an island, dressed in hair-covered goatskin clothingA furryRobinson CrusoeCrusoeshows the influence of SelkirkSelkirk's experience as a castaway aroused a great deal of attention in England. Rogers included an account of Selkirk's ordeal in a book chronicling their privateering expedition entitledA Cruising Voyage Round the World(1712). The following year, prominent essayistRichard Steelewrote an article about him forThe Englishmannewspaper. Selkirk appeared set to enjoy a life of ease and celebrity, claiming his share of theDuke'splundered wealthabout 800sfnpSteele1713173(equivalent toformatnum:today)Inflation-fnUK. However, legal disputes made the amount of any payment uncertain.sfnpSouhami2001180–181

After a few months inLondon, he began to seem more like his former self again.sfnpSteele1713173In September 1713, he was charged with assaulting a shipwright inBristoland may have been kept in confinement for two years.sfnpLee1987399; cf. [[#CITEREFSouhami2001|Souhami (2001)]], p. 186, "He did not show up for the hearing. He moved to the obscurity of London for some months, then went home to Largo."He returned to Lower Largo, where he met Sophia Bruce, a young dairymaid. They eloped to London early in 1717 but apparently did not marry. He was soon off to sea again, having enlisted in theRoyal Navy.sfnpSouhami2001190–192While on a visit toPlymouthin 1720, he married a widowed innkeeper named Frances Candis.sfnpSouhami2001201–202He was serving asmaster's mateon boardHMSWeymouth16936, engaged in an anti-Golden Age of Piracy#The post-Spanish-Succession periodpiracypatrol off the west coast of Africa, when he died on 13 December 1721, succumbing to theyellow feverthat plagued the voyage. He was buried at sea.sfnpSouhami2001203–205

WhenDaniel DefoepublishedRobinson CrusoeThe Life and Surprising Adventures of Robinson Crusoe(1719), few readers could have missed the resemblance to Selkirk. An illustration on the first page of the novel shows "a rather melancholy-looking man standing on the shore of an island, gazing inland", in the words of modern explorerTim Severin. He is dressed in the familiar hirsute goatskins, his feet and shins bare.sfnpSeverin200211Yet Crusoe's island is located not in themid-latitudesof the South Pacific butconvert4300kmmi-2onaway in theCaribbean SeaCaribbean, where the furry attire would hardly be comfortable in thetropical climatetropicalheat. This incongruity supports the popular belief that Selkirk was a model for the fictional character.sfnpSeverin200217

list.listitem: William Cowper's "The Solitude Of Alexander Selkirk" is about Selkirk's feelings as the castaway lived all alone on the island. This poem gave rise to the common phrase "monarch of all I survey" via the verse:citation neededJanuary 2014

paragraph.extension: I am monarch of all I survey,My right there is none to dispute;From the centre all round to the sea,I am lord of the fowl and the brute.

list.listitem: Charles Dickensused Selkirk as a simile in Chapter Two ofThe Pickwick Papers(1836): "Colonel Builder and Sir Thomas Clubber exchanged snuff-boxes, and looked very much like a pair of Alexander Selkirks'Monarchs of all they surveyed.'"This is also a reference to William Cowper's poem.
PoetPatrick Kavanaghlikens his loneliness on the road to that of Selkirk, in his poem "Inniskeen Road: July Evening":citation neededJanuary 2014

paragraph.extension: Oh, Alexander Selkirk knew the plightOf being king and government and nation.A road, a mile of kingdom, I am kingOf banks and stones and every blooming thing.

list.listitem: In "Etiquette", one ofW. S. Gilbert'sBab Ballads, Selkirk is used as a model for the English castaways:

paragraph.extension: These passengers, by reason of their clinging to a mast,Upon a desert island were eventually cast.They hunted for their meals, as Alexander Selkirk used,But they couldnt chat togetherthey had not been introduced.

list.listitem: Joshua Slocummentions Selkirk in the bookSailing Alone Around the World(1900). During his visit to the Juan Fernndez Islands, Slocum runs across a marker commemorating Selkirks stay.

InAllan ColeandChris Bunch's Sten science fiction series, Book Two,The Wolf Worlds, the Scottish character Alex bemoans their predicament after crash landing:"'A slackit way f'r a mon,' Alex mourned to himself. 'Ah didnae ken Ah'd ever be Alex Selkirk.'"

article.heading: In film
article.paragraph: Selkirk, the Real Robinson Crusoeis astop motionfilm byWalter Tournier, based on Selkirk's life. It premired simultaneously in Argentina, Chile, and Uruguay on 2 February 2012,cite newshttp://www.cinenacional.com/pelicula/selkirk-el-verdadero-robinson-crusoeSelkirk, el verdadero Robinson CrusoeCine Nacional2011distributed byThe Walt Disney Company. It was the first full-length animated feature to be produced in Uruguay.cite newshttp://www.elpais.com.uy/120804/pespec-655726/novedades/-selkirk-llega-al-dvd-con-algunas-novedades/Selkirk llega al DVD con algunas novedadesEl PaísApril 8, 2012
article.heading: Commemoration
article.paragraph: File:Alexander Selkirk Plaque.jpgthumbupright=1.6alt=Bronze plaque in memory of Selkirk affixed to a buildingPlaque for Selkirk inLower Largo, Scotland, which reads:"In memory of Alexander Selkirk, mariner, the original of Robinson Crusoe who lived on the island of Juan Fernndez in complete solitude for four years and four months. He diedSic17231721,Master's mate#Renaming and later uselieutenantof HMSWeymouth,Sicyaged 47 yearsaged 45 years. This statue is erected by David Gillies, net manufacturer, on the site of the cottage in which Selkirk was born."The Scotsman is remembered in his former island home. In 1863, the crew ofHMSTopaze18586placed a bronze tablet at a spot called Selkirk's Lookout on a hill of Ms a Tierra, Juan Fernndez Islands, to mark his stay.sfnpSeverin200259

Selkirk has also been memorialised in his Scottish birthplace.John Hamilton-Gordon, 1st Marquess of Aberdeen and TemairLord Aberdeendelivered a speech on 11 December 1885, after which his wifeIshbel Hamilton-Gordon, Marchioness of Aberdeen and TemairLady Aberdeenunveiled a bronze statue and plaque in memory of Selkirk outside a house on the site of his original home on the Main Street of Lower Largo, Fife, Scotland. David Gillies of Cardy House, Lower Largo, a descendant of the Selkirks, donated the statue created by Thomas Stuart BurnettRoyal Scottish AcademyARSA.cite newshttp://www.scotsindependent.org/dates1-f.htmNotable Dates in HistoryScots Independent2006

On 1 January 1966, Chilean presidentEduardo Frei Montalvarenamed Ms a TierraRobinson Crusoe Islandafter Defoe's fictional character, in order to attract tourists. At the same time, the largest of the Juan Fernndez Islands, known asMs Afuera, becameAlejandro Selkirk Island, although Selkirk probably never saw that island, since it is locatedconvert180kmmi nmi-1offto the west.sfnpSeverin200223–24
article.heading: Archaeological findings
article.paragraph: Anarchaeologicalexpedition to the Juan Fernndez Islands in February 2005 found part of a nautical instrument that could have belonged to Selkirk. It was "a fragment of copper alloy identified as being from a pair ofCaliper#Divider calipernavigational dividers"sfnpTakahashiCaldwellCáceresCalderón2007270dating from the early 18th (or late 17th) century. Selkirk is the only person known to have been on the island at that time who is likely to have had dividerssfnpTakahashiCaldwellCáceresCalderón2007294–295and was even said by Rogers to have had such instruments in his possession.sfnpRogers1712126The artefact was discovered while excavating a site not far from Selkirk's Lookout, where the famous castaway is believed to have lived.sfnpTakahashiCaldwellCáceresCalderón2007274–275
